Award.AwardTitle: Postprocessing and Data Analysis of Formaldehyde Measurements Aquired on the GV Aircraft During the 2012 Deep Convective Clouds and Chemistry Study
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves post-processing of original field data collected as part of the Deep Convective Clouds and Chemistry Study (DC3) conducted in May and June of 2012. The primary goal of the DC3 campaign was to determine the influence of deep, midlatitude continental convective clouds, including related dynamical, physical, and lightning processes, on upper tropospheric/lower stratospheric (UT/LS) composition and chemistry. In the UT/LS, formaldehyde and peroxides are major sources of ozone. Careful analyses of the DC3 dataset are important for understanding and interpreting radical production in the UT/LS due to convective transport of precursors that influence the production of ozone.

Data from the DC3 campaign will increase the understanding of the atmospheric chemistry and dynamics related to the formation of ozone in the upper troposphere, where ozone acts as a greenhouse gas. Detailed analysis of campaign data will help elucidate possible mechanisms that occur during deep convection and plume aging that influence water vapor, ozone, cirrus cloud and aerosol concentrations that all play important roles in contributing to radiative forcing of the Earth's climate system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The efficiency by which the soluble and reactive ozone (O3) precursor formaldehyde (CH2O) is removed (scavenged) from the gas phase during convection in various thunderstorms is critical for our understanding of O3 production in the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere. To address this question, we analyzed CH2O data acquired by two infrared spectrometers, built in our laboratory, which operated on the NASA DC-8 aircraft and the NSF/NCAR GV aircraft during the 2012 Deep Convective Clouds and Chemistry Study. Three strong thunderstorms storms were studied spanning a large geographic region of the United States (North-East Colorado, Central Oklahoma, Southern Missouri, Northern Alabama, Mississippi and Arkansas) with vastly different boundary layer compositions. Measurements of CH2O and hydrocarbon tracers in both the inflow and anvil outflow from these storms were analyzed employing two newly developed mixing models as well as a more sophisticated approach based upon high resolution simulations from Megan Bela and Mary Barth using the Weather Research and Forecasting Model with Chemistry (WRF-Chem) in one case. The CH2O scavenging efficiencies determined are remarkably consistent for the 3 strong convective cases studied (May 29, June 6, and June 11), both between storms and between the various approaches. The CH2O scavenging efficiency ranges between 40% and 65%, and in each case the various approaches are in agreement within the stated 1σ estimated precisions. The results of this study, which are supported by numerous crosschecks, careful measurements, and careful analysis to avoid systematic errors, point to the important fact that approximately 50% of the reactive trace gas CH2O is directly transported to the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere during convection. This consistency in results between different storms is in contrast to previous studies, which yield results that are both significantly lower and span a much larger range.

A second noteworthy finding is the suggestion from the WRF-Chem modeling studies that as liquid drops in the various thunderstorms freeze upon ascending from cloud base to the anvil outflow regions, CH2O is not retained in the ice phase. Analysis of additional CH2O measurements acquired by the PI Fried and his group during a 2013 NASA study of convection over the South-Eastern United States are providing additional evidence to support the hypothesis that CH2O is completely rejected from ice. If substantiated by further evidence, this will provide an important piece of information that addresses a heretofore highly uncertain parameter in atmospheric models of convective transport.
